UI_visible_response: Mass surveillance in the People's Republic of China (PRC) involves an extensive network of monitoring systems utilized by the central government to oversee its citizens. This surveillance apparatus is particularly prominent in regions like Xinjiang, where Chinese authorities have been reported to use a mobile app for illegal mass surveillance and arbitrary detention, primarily targeting the Muslim population3. The reach of digital surveillance in China is pervasive, becoming a staple aspect of daily life; citizens are adapting by developing mental strategies to cope with this reality4. Furthermore, facial recognition technology is employed by police agencies across China’s cities, which are equipped with more CCTV cameras than any other cities globally5. This extensive surveillance infrastructure underscores the limited privacy available to individuals within the country, reflecting on the broader implications of technological advancements made by companies such as Dahua, one of the largest surveillance camera providers worldwide7.
traffic_visible_response: Mass surveillance in the People's Republic of China (PRC) involves an extensive network of monitoring systems utilized by the central government to oversee its citizens. This surveillance apparatus is particularly prominent in regions like Xinjiang, where Chinese authorities have been reported to use a mobile app for illegal mass surveillance and arbitrary detention, primarily targeting the Muslim population [[3]]. The reach of digital surveillance in China is pervasive, becoming a staple aspect of daily life; citizens are adapting by developing mental strategies to cope with this reality [[4]]. Furthermore, facial recognition technology is employed by police agencies across China’s cities, which are equipped with more CCTV cameras than any other cities globally [[5]]. This extensive surveillance infrastructure underscores the limited privacy available to individuals within the country, reflecting on the broader implications of technological advancements made by companies such as Dahua, one of the largest surveillance camera providers worldwide [[7]].
